sub_title: Flexible Physicist | Digital Fabricator | Loves Cooking
summary:
I am a flexible physicist with broad expertise leading the development of complex optical systems. A unique mixture of applied academic researcher and practical systems engineer, with a fearless attitude towards new tools, measurement techniques, and collaborations.


Technical skills: physics, optical design,  optical sensors (spectrometers [PL and absorption], single-photon counting, [PicoHarp], CCD Arrays), light sources (CW and pulsed lasers [ns, ps, fs pulses], white-light generation), alignment methods, system modeling, data analysis, information synthesis, laser systems, 3D printing, Lithography, CAD, imaging, microscopy, consulting, teaching.

awards.title: 2nd Prize in Lights Contest
awards.description:
I created a tutorial that teaches makers how to use Fusion360 to create a scaled-model lighthouse, then how to export it to be cut out of wood using a laser cutter.  Judging was done Instructables's community Makers and by prize judges.

https://vzoutenbier.wordpress.com/portfolio/lighthouse/

awards.description: Crafted a compelling research story to generate enthusiasm for 1st year graduate students to join our research group (20% of incoming students joined our group over a dozen others!)

projects.title: Time-Correlated Single Photon Counting
projects.description: We designed and built a femto-second laser setup to collect time-correlated single-photon counting measurements (using a Pico-harp).  This allowed us to study the time dynamics of photoluminescence emitted by rubrene single crystals.

contributors.headline: Flexible Physicist | Digital Fabricator | Loves Cooking
Research Physicist at the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory

projects.title: Time-Correlated White Light Spectroscopy Experiments
projects.description: Our team developed an optical setup that could test the time dynamics of rubrene's absorption spectrum using broad-wavelength, visible spectrometers. This project required us to develop hardware and software components to measure a very sensitive signal.

contributors.headline: Flexible Physicist | Digital Fabricator | Loves Cooking
Associate Professor of Physics at Massachusetts College of Liberal Arts
Research Physicist at the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory

projects.title: Photoluminescence Yield of Rubrene
projects.description: I mentored Michael through a series of optical experiments to test the relative photoluminescence yield from rubrene single crystals. This was part of his summer NSF research project.

contributors.headline: Flexible Physicist | Digital Fabricator | Loves Cooking

projects.title: Electric Field Studies of Photoconductivity
projects.description: Ludic and I conducted experiments to test for an electric-field dependence of photoconductivity in rubrene.

projects.title: Four-Wave Mixing Experiments
projects.description: Assembled, aligned, and collected data on exciton dynamics in rubrene using an exciton diffraction grating created in a collinear four-wave mixing optical setup.

profile_positions.description:
Scientist in the Medical Photonics group within the optics department, developing new diagnostics and sensing tools for healthcare applications. 

Leading developer in Monte Carlo simulations for skin, eye, and industrial applications.
profile_positions.title: Scientist Specialist

profile_positions.description:
•	TKI Retinal Oxymetry project, a collaboration between Heidelberg Engineering, TNO, and VU:
o	Leading design, implementation, and use of an ex-corpus human blood-flow system to allow for validation of in-vivo OCT/SLO measurements. Includes control engineering for flow rate, system temperature, and gas mixtures with several other diagnostic measurements logged by LabView
o	Collaborating with TNO Delft machine shop to make molds for a model eyes
o	Leveraged bachelor student research interests to develop in-line method for sensing blood oxygenation level using a flow-through cell and broadband transmission spectroscopy.
•	Lead PhD and Master’s students through technical background required to implement complex systems, such as mechanical mirror control for raster scanning and high-speed DAQ
•	Pushed projects through conceptualization and proposal stages to secure a long-term project blood supply and to pass a CCMO-approved human clinical trial at vumc using a research device
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Researcher

profile_positions.description: Partnered with Oogheelkunde (ophthalmology) department for clinical trial of new polarization-sensitive OCT device.  Scanned four patient groups along with control healthy volunteers to look for early indicators of eye disease in naturally-occurring birefringent materials in the eye.
profile_positions.title: Visiting Fellow

profile_positions.description:
o	Developing a Raman spectroscopy technique to measure water-based coating thickness and trace fluid components.
o	Conducting media development studies of color gamut, image grain, and dye density to improve image quality on thermal imaging media.
o	Coding MATLAB scripts to analyze historical media calibration data
o	Identified solutions to mitigate severe static electricity discharge created during coating process.
o	Supporting Zink’s Whitsett, NC manufacturing facility by working with the media calibration, coating process, and dispersion/fluid formulation teams toward common goal of improved media quality. o	Acted as primary point of contact for a new Asian partner.  Responsible for all imaging/color calibrations as well as remote/in-house partner support.
o	Created documentation for in-house tools, which were shared with a joint-development partner.
profile_positions.title: Senior Scientist

profile_positions.description:
Summary:
My dissertation improves our understanding of a material (rubrene) that is able to capture energy usually wasted in current solar panel technologies. This material is able to break energy absorbed from the sun from one big piece into two smaller pieces that can move, recombine, then be collected more efficiently.

This research is important because it frames our understanding of abstract quantum-mechanical processes as a useful tool. A tool that can be used to help develop more efficient solar cells.  My experimental data and analyses provide a fundamental exploration of these processes for future researchers to build on-top of and extend into other materials.

Key Achievements:

•	Delivered 3 large research projects by optimizing laboratory workflows while mentoring 5 scientists. Recognized for work with 3 fellowship awards.

•	Designed modular optical microscope to perform a variety of experiments, expanding the research team’s capabilities and avoiding the purchase of a commercial product worth 25% of our annual budget.

•	Coordinated the design and testing of a technical hardware & software project in collaboration with 4 other research professionals.

•	Trained other scientists on optical alignment methods for large UV-VIS-NIR optical systems and developed alignment tools and sensors. 

•	Synthesized actionable information from large, detailed data sets using numerical analysis techniques

•	Created a nonlinear numerical simulation in Mathematica to explain the power-dependent change of PL contributions seen in a physical data set with 5+ experimental axes.

•	Purchased and utilized a wide range of optical systems resulting in expert-level market knowledge.

•	Experienced public speaker from regular progress meetings and 4 poster presentations (2 presenter awards.)

•	Developed physical vapors deposition method for amorphous rubrene.
profile_positions.title: Research Scientist

profile_positions.description:
Key Achievements:

•	Guided and supported undergraduate physics students through  3 years of demanding courses with workshop and laboratory components, student feedback averages over 4.5+/5 with outstanding comments.

•	Communicated technical concepts effectively by breaking information down into manageable chunks and presented them in a logical pattern. 

•	Demonstrated teaching abilities to students with a wide range of mathematical and scientific backgrounds through 4 different courses.

Summary:
I was responsible for all aspect of teaching, except presenting new content, to two biweekly sections of physics.  This includes reviewing and restating challenging concepts, identifying the  best teaching strategy for each topic, working with students to troubleshoot homework, and grading all assignments.
profile_positions.title: Teaching Assistant

profile_positions.description:
Key Skills:

•	Instinctive client-facing skills with positive customer service interactions in safety-critical roles as evidenced by several positive feedback cards from guests, managers, and fellow team members.

•	Excellent relationship building experience in dynamic teams ranging in size from 2 to 100 members.

Summary:
I held three roles at Disney World during high school and college.  First, I was a deep water lifeguard at Blizzard Beach for two summers.  I then transferred to Kilimanjaro Safaris where I  drove through the Harambe Wildlife Reserve as a safari guide for three summers. I enjoyed showing the beautiful African animals to eager children (and adults).  My favorite animal was the Thomson's Gazelle (they're so cute!) Finally, I spent a summer in the Asia themed area of Animal Kingdom at Expedition Everest, where I helped tame the Yeti.
profile_positions.title: Safari Guide and Lifeguard

profile_positions.description:
Key Achievements:

• Researched and designed a model of an avalanching system that could be tested in the lab.

• Coded a method in MATLAB to trace single particles in a high-speed video feed of avalanche systems.

• Synthesized useful information from Gb's of data with visual plots and statistical averaging methods.

Summary:
The research project studied how a single grain behaves in a large avalanching system.  It was an interesting entry point for fundamental research because it combined a visual physical experiment with a coded motion-tracking function I wrote specifically for this experiment.
profile_positions.title: Visiting Researcher

volunteer_experiences.description:
•	Repaired, serviced, and integrated all digital fabrication equipment; including photolithography-based 3D printer and a CNC laser cutter.

•	Advised and implemented client-focused upgrades aimed at reducing the learning curve of equipment and workflow improvements (reduced material waste by over 50%.)

•	Prepared documentation for a high-resolution 3D printer for an audience with a wide variety of backgrounds.

•	Created enthusiasm for the local makerspace community through outreach projects at Wake Up the Earth festival (giant spin art machine!) and the Mini Maker Fair at Boston Children's Museum (stackable cats cutouts!)

See my makerspace portfolio at www.vzoutenbier.wordpress.com

Visualizing Inman Square Redesign
-  Collaborating with a zoning official, I created a virtual reality scene of the redesigned Inman Square traffic pattern in Sketch Up which was used to help the public understand changes in the new traffic pattern at a neighborhood meeting.
Project Hope
- As part of a large team I synthesized information on social benefits such as MassCare, CHIP, and SNAP to make logic-based coding algorithms.

CHOICES is a week-long camp for middle-school girls to get involved and excited about STEM fields. I worked directly with the department outreach coordinator to create a lesson plan for the physics portion of the camp to show how light can be used to learn about what we can't see.
Assisted in organization, scheduling, advertisement, and logistics of hosting a specialized conference on nonlinear optics at Lehigh University.

Collected physics graduate students' concerns and presented them to the advisory committee to identify areas of college success or improvement.  We then brainstormed ways to fix the areas that need improvement by working with the dean's office and communicated the suggestions back to our department.

Published articles in UP include:
- Rainy Day Physics: The Physics of Staying Dry
- Basic MATLAB: for Physics Majors!.

Helped plan for high school teams from Central Florida to participate in a game-show like team quiz.  I acted as the running host of operations for the 2011 Science Bowl by managing volunteers and creating match brackets for the competition while tracking team scores.
